content: Interesting word, "bipartisan." By "bipartisan," do you mean fair, or do you mean one that you would be willing to agree with because it sufficiently limits the ability of gays to serve? All evidence in your posts points to the fact that you will throw up any roadblock you can think of to full and honest service by gays, full or partial. You spend so much time dreaming up objections and reasons that it shouldn't be so that you miss how simple the process has been in practice i other militaries that we base our own military traditions upon. The proposal you refer to is not just unworkable, it is chilling in its scope and based on a premise of pure fantasy. It has a juvenile understanding of sexuality, and a basis in fear. Here is a counter-proposal for you, and I don't even need 14 pages to explain it (oh, wait, but I'm "on ignore" for failure to agree with you): 1. Afford gays and bisexuals the same opportunities, rights, and responsibilities in their private lives as straights. 2. Kick gays, bisexuals and straights out of the military when their attitude towards sexuality of any kind becomes a problem. In explanation, if a gay person sexually harasses any other person, gay or straight, kick them out. Ditto for straight people. If a servicemember uses sexual favors, gay or straight, to procure favorable treatment, kick them out. If a gay, bisexual or straight person physically theatens or bullies another member due to sexual preference, kick the bully out. Make the rules zero tolerance, and make them apply equally across the board. 3. Bring UCMJ articles on sexual behavior in line with the standard the US Supreme Court has set for civilian governments. It really is that simple. It is interesting that you advocate a proposal with oodles of restrictions and tracking for gays, but none for straights. It seems that you still feel that gays are predatory, and that straights need to be somehow protected from this minority class. That is a prejudicial attitude at heart, whether you recognizer it or not.

By "bipartisan," do you mean fair, or do you mean one that you would be willing to agree with because it sufficiently limits the ability of gays to serve? All evidence in your posts points to the fact that you will throw up any roadblock you can think of to full and honest service by gays, full or partial. You spend so much time dreaming up objections and reasons that it shouldn't be so that you miss how simple the process has been in practice i other militaries that we base our own military traditions upon. The proposal you refer to is not just unworkable, it is chilling in its scope and based on a premise of pure fantasy. It has a juvenile understanding of sexuality, and a basis in fear. Here is a counter-proposal for you, and I don't even need 14 pages to explain it (oh, wait, but I'm "on ignore" for failure to agree with you): 1. Afford gays and bisexuals the same opportunities, rights, and responsibilities in their private lives as straights. 2. Kick gays, bisexuals and straights out of the military when their attitude towards sexuality of any kind becomes a problem. In explanation, if a gay person sexually harasses any other person, gay or straight, kick them out. Ditto for straight people. If a servicemember uses sexual favors, gay or straight, to procure favorable treatment, kick them out. If a gay, bisexual or straight person physically theatens or bullies another member due to sexual preference, kick the bully out. Make the rules zero tolerance, and make them apply equally across the board. 3. Bring UCMJ articles on sexual behavior in line with the standard the US Supreme Court has set for civilian governments. It really is that simple. It is interesting that you advocate a proposal with oodles of restrictions and tracking for gays, but none for straights. It seems that you still feel that gays are predatory, and that straights need to be somehow protected from this minority class. That is a prejudicial attitude at heart, whether you recognizer it or not. I notice that this counterproposal doesn't include the repeal of DADT, so perhaps there is room to discuss what I've advocated, i.e. modification of the existing DADT policy?

content: quote: i.e. modification of the existing DADT policy? DA (don't ask), yes, that part could/should remain. Modify DT (don't tell) to say only on a voluntary basis. No punishment for being free and honest. Otherwise, drop the entire silly rule and let people of minority sexual orientation who qualify to serve in the military do so with the same level of freedom and opportunity the major orientation enjoys. Everything else to deal with any problems that might arise are already in place in the military. Nothing more need to be done.... ...oh, maybe a briefing or two for those who "don't get it" with the usual warnings of consequences for harassment, etc. That's the only reasonable "modification".
